facts.text: Rule 6 of Protection Rules guarantees conditions of service re pay, allowances, leave, pension not less favourable than before 1st April 1936.

construction of Rule 6 of the Rules issued by the Governor-General in Council on the 15th September, 1936, for the protection of members of a Provincial or Subordinate service required to serve in, or in connection with, the affairs of Orissa hereinafter called the Protection Rules .

concepts.interpretation: Guarantees that conditions of service as respects pay, allowances, leave and pension shall not be less favourable than before 1st April 1936, but does not extend to claims for promotion or confirmation in higher selection posts.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 6 of the Protection Rules reads thus The conditions of service as respects pay, allowances leave and pension of any member of Provincial or Subordinate service serving immediately before the 1st day of April, 1936 in or in connection with the affairs of the province of Bihar Orissa,

concepts.interpretation: Does not cover promotion to selection posts as such promotions depend on vacancies, seniority, merits, etc., and are not part of protected conditions.

issues.text: raises a short question about the construction of Rule 6 of the Rules issued by the Governor-General in Council on the 15th September, 1936, for the protection of members of a Provincial or Subordinate service required to serve in, or in connection with, the affairs of Orissa

anchor.surface_text: rraises a short question about the companystruction of Rule 6 of the Rules issued by the Governor-General in Council on the 15th September, 1936, for the protection of members of a Provincial or Subordinate service required to serve in, or in companynection with, the affairs of Orissa  hereinafter called the Protection Rules . These Rules were framed by the Governor-General in Council in exercise of the powers companyferred on him by section 23 2  of the Government of India  Construction of Orissa  Order, 1936,

issues.text: The question is do any of the conditions specified in R. 6 include a claim for promotion to a higher selection post and confirmation in it

anchor.surface_text: The question is do any of the conditions specified in R. 6 include a claim for promotion to a higher selection post and companyfirmation in it. It is well known that promotion to a selection post is number a matter of right which can be claimed merely by seniority. Normally, in companysidering the question of a public servants claim for promotion to a selection post, his seniority and his merits have to be companysidered and so, it seems to us very difficult to accept the view taken by the High Court that in R. 6 of the Protection Rules, a guarantee can be inferred in regard to promotion to a selection post.

Proceeding to deal with this problem on the basis of these two assumptions, the High Court has thought it reasonable to draw the inference that the respondent would certainly have been promoted as Registrar and companyfirmed as such, at the latest, on the 23rd August, 1956,

issues.text: the Rules of promotion which would have governed his case if he had continued in Bihar, are radically different from the Rules of promotion which were introduced in Orissa after his services were transferred to Orissa, and that, he contends, is a contravention of R. 6 of the Protection Rules

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Andley for the respondent attempted to argue that the respondent had received unfair treatment in as much as the Rules of promotion which would have governed his case if he had companytinued in Bihar, are radically different from the Rules of promotion which were introduced in Orissa after his services were transferred to Orissa, and that, he companytends, is a companytravention of R. 6 of the Protection Rules. The relevant rule in Bihar for promotion is R. 2 1  it reads thus Rule 2 1 -Registrar,- The post of Registrar  Pay B 0 Old ScaleRs. 500-20-600 - B 0 Revised Scale-Rs. 450-20- 550  in the Secretariat is a Gazetted and belongs to the General Provincial service.

issues.text: in view of another specific instance where the entitlement to salary of a Registrar was determined by reference to the date when an officer junior to him in the Bihar service was promoted as Registrar, the treatment meted out to the respondent was discriminatory

anchor.surface_text: In the appeal to this Court, it was also companytended, inter alia, that in view of another specific instance where the entitlement to salary of a Registrar was determined by reference to the date when an officer junior to him in the Bihar service was promoted as Registrar, the treatment meted out to the respondent was discriminatory. HELD The High Courts order must be set aside and the respondents writ petition dismissed.

arguments.court_reasoning: Agrees Rule 6 protects only specified conditions, not promotion.

arguments.claim: Rule 6 protects conditions of service re pay, allowances, leave, pension but does not include promotion to higher selection post.

anchor.surface_text: The Rule in question protects the conditions of service as respects pay, allowances, leave and pension of the members falling under its purview, and it guarantees that in no case shall the terms in relation to the said conditions of service be less favourable than they were immediately before the 1st of April, 1936.

arguments.claim: Promotion to selection post not matter of right by seniority alone; requires merits, outside Rule 6 guarantee.

anchor.surface_text: The question is do any of the conditions specified in R. 6 include a claim for promotion to a higher selection post and confirmation in it. It is well known that promotion to a selection post is not a matter of right which can be claimed merely by seniority.

arguments.claim: Cannot indirectly claim promotion via pension calculation under Rule 6.

anchor.surface_text: In other words, the High Court seems to have taken the view that though promotion and confirmation in particular posts cannot be claimed directly under R. 6, a claim in that behalf can be indirectly permitted if it has a bearing on the amount of pension to which a transferred public servant would be entitled on retirement.

arguments.court_reasoning: If direct claim outside, indirect also not permitted.

arguments.claim: Promotion rules in Bihar (R.2(1)) radically different from Orissa rules (R.6-9), contravening Rule 6.
arguments.court_reasoning: No evidence of substantial difference; both involve selection from similar pools.

arguments.claim: Under Bihar rule promotion by seniority, Orissa by seniority-cum-merit, prejudicial under Rule 6.
arguments.court_reasoning: Bihar also seniority-cum-merit; no material or High Court finding.

arguments.claim: Treatment discriminatory because Mr. Beuria (similarly transferred) got Registrar pay from 1 Dec 1948 based on his junior's Bihar promotion.
arguments.court_reasoning: Beuria case outside Rule 6 or misconstrues it; cannot justify similar misconstruction.

arguments.claim: Joint PSC 1939 and Governor 1942 instructions support protection of promotion prospects under Rule 6.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that in 1939, a question arose whether the prospects of promotion of transferred officers were protected by the Protection Rules, and the Joint Public Service Commission for Bihar, Orissa, and the Central Provinces, which was functioning in 1939, took the view that the said Rules must be interpreted to require that an officer transferred from Bihar and Orissa to Orissa shall have prospects of promotion as good as he would have had in Bihar and Orissa,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: tion under R. 2 1  of the Bihar Rules companyld have been intended to be made only by reference to seniority. The very companycept of selection involv

arguments.court_reasoning: Not binding on court; court interprets Rule directly.

holdings.text: The conditions of service protected by Rule 6 of the Protection Rules as respects pay, allowances, leave and pension do not include a claim for promotion to a higher selection post and confirmation therein.

anchor.surface_text: The question is do any of the conditions specified in R. 6 include a claim for promotion to a higher selection post and confirmation in it. It is well known that promotion to a selection post is not a matter of right which can be claimed merely by seniority. Normally, in considering the question of a public servants claim for promotion to a selection post, his seniority and his merits have to be considered and so, it seems to us very difficult to accept the view taken by the High Court that in R. 6 of the Protection Rules, a guarantee can be inferred in regard to promotion to a selection post.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of Rule 6 specifies only pay, allowances, leave, pension; promotion to selection post not a matter of right, depends on seniority, merits, vacancies, not guaranteed condition.

holdings.text: A claim for promotion to a selection post cannot be indirectly permitted under Rule 6 even if it bears on the amount of pension.

anchor.surface_text: In other words, the High Court seems to have taken the view that though promotion and confirmation in particular posts cannot be claimed directly under R. 6, a claim in that behalf can be indirectly permitted if it has a bearing on the amount of pension to which a transferred public servant would be entitled on retirement.

holdings.reasoning_summary: If direct claim for promotion excluded from Rule 6, indirect claim via pension impact also excluded to avoid circumventing the rule's scope.

holdings.text: To determine contravention of Rule 6, it is neither relevant nor material to inquire when the transferred officer would have been promoted if continued in Bihar service.

anchor.surface_text: the other assumption is that in determining the question as to whether the provision as to the said protection has been contravened, it would be relevant and material to enquire when the officer in question would have been promoted to a corresponding post if he had continued in service in Bihar. Proceeding to deal with this problem on the basis of these two assumptions, the High Court has thought it reasonable to draw the inference that the respondent would certainly have been promoted as Registrar and confirmed as such, at the latest, on the 23rd August, 1956,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Such hypothetical inquiry impractical and unreasonable given multiple variables like vacancies, merits; outside contemplation of Rule 6.

holdings.text: The promotion rules applicable in Bihar (Rule 2(1)) and Orissa (Rules 6-9) are not radically or substantially different so as to contravene Rule 6 of the Protection Rules.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of substantial difference in selection pools or criteria; both involve consultation with PSC and consideration from eligible officers.

holdings.text: Promotion to Registrar under Bihar Rule 2(1) is by selection ordinarily from Section Heads, involving seniority-cum-merit, not pure seniority.

anchor.surface_text: The very concept of selection involves the consideration of seniority coupled with merit, which is generally described as the seniority-cum-merit test.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concept of 'selection' inherently requires seniority plus merit assessment; no material supports pure seniority claim.

holdings.text: The respondent's treatment is not discriminatory merely because Mr. Beuria, another transferred officer, was granted Registrar pay from an earlier date based on a junior's Bihar promotion.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Beuria decision prima facie outside or misconstrues Rule 6; one misconstruction does not justify or bind similar treatment in other cases.

holdings.text: Administrative interpretations by Joint PSC (1939) and Governor of Orissa (1942) do not materially bear on the court's construction of Rule 6.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that in 1939, a question arose whether the prospects of promotion of transferred officers were protected by the Protection Rules, and the Joint Public Service Commission for Bihar, Orissa, and the Central Provinces, which was functioning in 1939, took the view that the said Rules must be interpreted to require that an officer transferred from Bihar and Orissa to Orissa shall have prospects of promotion as good as he would have had in Bihar and Orissa,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court independently construes rule based on text, spirit, object; administrative views relevant but not binding.

anchor.surface_text: The result is, the appeal is allowed, the order passed by the High Court is set aside, and the writ petition filed by the respondent is dismissed.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; High Court order set aside; writ petition of the respondent dismissed

anchor.surface_text: was companyfirmed as a Registrar and the argument which found favour with the High Court was that in determining this amount, it would be relevant to

edges.explanation: Holding span overlaps issue span and directly answers whether Rule 6 includes promotion to selection post.

anchor.surface_text: The question is do any of the conditions specified in R. 6 include a claim for promotion to a higher selection post and confirmation in it. It is well known that promotion to a selection post is not a matter of right which can be claimed merely by seniority. Normally, in considering the question of a public servants claim for promotion to a selection post, his seniority and his merits have to be considered and so, it seems to us very difficult to accept the view taken by the High Court that in R. 6 of the Protection Rules, a guarantee can be inferred in regard to promotion to a selection post.
The result is, the appeal is allowed, the order passed by the High Court is set aside, and the writ petition filed by the respondent is dismissed.
ve effect from 1-12-1948. It does appear that this order was passed on the basis that Mr. Beuria was entitled to the salary of a Registrar, because Mr

edges.explanation: Holding no indirect promotion claim supports exclusion concept

anchor.surface_text: In other words, the High Court seems to have taken the view that though promotion and confirmation in particular posts cannot be claimed directly under R. 6, a claim in that behalf can be indirectly permitted if it has a bearing on the amount of pension to which a transferred public servant would be entitled on retirement.
The result is, the appeal is allowed, the order passed by the High Court is set aside, and the writ petition filed by the respondent is dismissed.

the other assumption is that in determining the question as to whether the provision as to the said protection has been contravened, it would be relevant and material to enquire when the officer in question would have been promoted to a corresponding post if he had continued in service in Bihar. Proceeding to deal with this problem on the basis of these two assumptions, the High Court has thought it reasonable to draw the inference that the respondent would certainly have been promoted as Registrar and confirmed as such, at the latest, on the 23rd August, 1956,
The result is, the appeal is allowed, the order passed by the High Court is set aside, and the writ petition filed by the respondent is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The very concept of selection involves the consideration of seniority coupled with merit, which is generally described as the seniority-cum-merit test.
The result is, the appeal is allowed, the order passed by the High Court is set aside, and the writ petition filed by the respondent is dismissed.

edges.explanation: Holding on administrative interpretations not materially bearing on court's construction of Rule 6 directly addresses the issue of Rule 6 construction.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that in 1939, a question arose whether the prospects of promotion of transferred officers were protected by the Protection Rules, and the Joint Public Service Commission for Bihar, Orissa, and the Central Provinces, which was functioning in 1939, took the view that the said Rules must be interpreted to require that an officer transferred from Bihar and Orissa to Orissa shall have prospects of promotion as good as he would have had in Bihar and Orissa,
The result is, the appeal is allowed, the order passed by the High Court is set aside, and the writ petition filed by the respondent is dismissed.
